title: 110_hr5469
content: SECTION 1. WATERFRONT BROWNFIELDS GRANT. Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to establish a program for grants to eligible entities or nonprofit organizations for waterfront brownfields revitalization. Grants can be used for reuse planning, site characterization, assessment, or remediation at waterfront brownfield sites. The amendment to Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 establishes a grant program for waterfront brownfields revitalization. Grants can be used for activities such as water quality improvements, low impact development approaches, green infrastructure, sediment management, and flood damage prevention at brownfield sites adjacent to bodies of water. The grant program for waterfront brownfields revitalization under Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 authorizes appropriations of $220,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012. $55,000,000 of this amount is designated for specific use. The grant program for waterfront brownfields revitalization under Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 authorizes appropriations of $220,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012, with $55,000,000 designated for site characterization, assessment, and remediation of facilities. Additionally, funds are authorized for waterfront brownfields revitalization grants. SEC. 2. TASK FORCE. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will establish a task force on waterfront brownfields revitalization. Members will include experts from various organizations such as the EPA, NOAA, Army Corps of Engineers, DOT, HUD, EDA, Fish and Wildlife Service, state and local governments, community-based organizations, and other interested parties. Additional members may be included at the Administrator's discretion. The task force on waterfront brownfields revitalization, established by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will identify funding resources, barriers, and coordination methods for revitalization efforts. A report on the findings must be submitted to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment.
